entry.para: Obtain a thorough symptom picture and assessment of psychological, interpersonal, and vocational functioning in order to make a differential diagnosis, especially in patients who present with substance abuse, affective disorder, anxiety, and/or interpersonal or work-related problems

Fail to consider how symptoms may impact style of reporting; individuals with PDs may have a grandiose self-image (i. e., narcissistic PD), an overly dramatic manner of speaking (i. e., histrionic PD), or a wary suspiciousness which may not be readily disclosed (i. e., paranoid PD) or the individual may lack insight/forthrightness
Share diagnostic impressions with the patient in the setting of providing psychoeducation and identifying treatment goals
Provide a diagnosis without sufficient psychoeducation; PDs are highly stigmatized and poorly understood by the general public and misinformation exists on internet
Use the patient’s words or preface interventions with comments such as “as you said earlier” to maintain rapport and help the patient more readily accept clinician’s comments and recommendations
Follow semi-structured interviews to the letter, they are semi-structured for a reason; ask further clarifying questions and for examples from the client’s life
Consider your own biases based on gender, race, SES, age, sexual orientation, etc. when making a diagnosis; consider cultural context
Fail to consider how PDs may present differently by gender, age, culture, etc. For example, a young man with borderline PD may present differently than an older woman with borderline PD
Consider the onset, course, and duration of symptoms; PDs are disorders that must be present across time and context
Rely on heuristics based solely on “clinical experience” to diagnose a PD; it is important that all symptoms are assessed for in making diagnostic decisions and no areas are left out
